content.description:
Located to the climbers left of the obvious cave. Scramble to the first bolt, make the move and go up and right toward the cave. From the cave, traverse out left then climb straight up (crux) to a good ledge where it meets up with Sweetness is in the Hand of the Beeholder. This route is short but has surprisingly fun movement. Like most of the routes in this area, don't forget to turn around and enjoy the view :) Climber's Left of the obvious cave Sport (6 bolts)
2 bolt Anchor with chain
  • *The rock quality to the left of the cave is not the best. The loose rock has been trundled and the remaining rock has been pried on with a bar. That being said, there is still a potential for rock to break off. Please be careful**

This is the longest route in Greenhead. Start on the ground, below and to the climbers right of the cave. Follow 4 bolts up a face, trending left into the cave (5.6ish) *There are 2 bolts to the climbers right of the cave that protect the crux. The second (higher) bolt can be reachy so if youre not concerned about the onsight, feel free to rappel and pre-hang a draw or even extend it if youre really short.** Climbing out of the cave (crux) is some of the best climbing in the city. Very cool natural features and fun, funky roof climbing leads to a ledge above the cave. Clip a bolt and climb up and left through a fun face past 2 more bolts. (*Climbing the face avoids the chossy corner*) From here, climb straight up the easy top section passing one last bolt on your way to a chain anchor. Dont forget to turn around and enjoy the view :) Sport(10)  2 bolt anchor with chain

Rappelling this route with a 70m rope is recommended. there's only about 3-4m of rope on the ground when using the 70m and I have yet to try to rap with a 60m rope.

Start on the right side of the wall underneath the big block forming a roof. Clip the first bolt by standing on the large chair like rock. First move is tough, clip the next bolt form under the roof then move right out from under the roof then up the hand crack on the sight side. Once above the block, traverse left on good hand hold clipping another bolt at the end of the traverse. The final boulder problem is protected by a bolt and offers the best climbing on the vertical to slightly over hanging headwall.

Right side of the main face
This route could use another bolt somewhere between 2ed and 3rd, there is potential for a 20' fall that you would stop above the ground. But due to the death block not sure what the options are, currently working on figuring it out.

climbs.name: Donkey following Carrots
climbs.fa: Ian Lingley/ Eric Fox/ Eric Samis

content.description:
After the scramble. Traverse across a good foot ledge with great exposure clipping a bolt half way. At the end of the ledge clip another bolt then follow the bolts straight up to the top of the cliff. If rappelling from the top TIE KNOTS.    
 This climb is a little chossy but with great exposure. 

Climb the 5.1 gully, half way up go right to a few cedars trees with a bolt or two behind them, belay from here.
6 bolts + 2 raprings

This route is basically 'Don't be Jenga Direct'. Same start, but move left around the roof instead of right. A relatively short (but excellent) boulder problem will join you back onto Don't be Jenga just in time for the crux at the top. In my opinion, it's the best sport route in Saint John. Very fun. 
 I am not good at grading, I gave it a 5.12- because its harder then Don't be Jenga (5.11+) but I don't know by how much. please climb it and let me know :)

Straight up the big obvious (slightly overhanging) face that begs to be climbed. Stay left of the giant block/flake
7 bolts and chains on a 2 bolt anchor

climbs.name: Good Looking Bat Hooking
climbs.fa: Ian Lingley, Cory Hall, Eric Samis

content.description:
This incredible line follows the white streak up the center of this amazing blank face passing horizontal pin seams and finishing in water grooved limestone for the last 20. This is an extremely blank face which the first 40' will require bat hooking between bolts and the occasional fixed piton. Towards the top of the climb there are more natural features/gear placements, where offset nuts with the use of a few small cams and a few pins or hooks placement will allow you to get to the anchor. I truly hope that someone strong comes along and makes a free accent of this spectacular limestone overhanging wall, it could be free climbed around the 5.17b/c range. Right up the center of the crazy blank face. Hooks(2min), Pitons, standard rack, offset nut, Hammer
This line could be done clean(no hammer) still using hooks and with the use of a couple fixed pins.

This could also be top roped from a few small cedars, and would make for a good practice aid.

This route might be the most thought provoking aid routes in New Brunswick, it entails tough hooking, tricky cam placements, piton hammering and scary runouts resulting in extravagant experience. This is not for the beginner aid climber and it would be strongly recommended to practice on other aid lines in New Brunswick before testing your luck on this one. 



This route is on the main face at green head Cove just left of good looking bad hooking. 

Two hooks, quick draws,  pitons and cams up to one inch.

climbs.name: Sweetness is in the hand of the beeholder

content.description:
Start on a large ledge left of the cave. Start on a good hold to clip the first bolt, follow the bolts through a small overhang/undercling, continue following the bolts up and right to an anchor. I would recommend moving a little left at this point and continue on Donkey following carrots 5.5 to the very top of the cliff. You can rap from the lower anchor, or if at the top of the cliff walk off or rap from the tree right of the anchor tie knots in the end if raping from the tree.

This climb is located left of the cave on the ledge and requires 20' of scrambling on class 4 terrain to get to the ledge.
4 Bolts + 2 raprings

Ground up first accent using a hammer drill,pitons, cams, bathooks, bolts from Canadian Tire and a haul line to pull up a tall can every 10 feet. 
  
 If you blow a piece of gear at the top of this route you'll be looking at a 40+ foot whipper, Have Fun!!

up the steepest blankest secton of the main wall.
5 bolts, and some holes to bathook or slide a non-expantion bolts in and remove them when your done. a few cams and couple pitons. + you might want some beer.

The main cliff is the extremely blank face approximately 100 feet tall and slightly overhanging. This could house the hardest lines in N.B and with work could have a few test pieces on it. It starts at the escape gully/cave and continues across the black face until the rock becomes blocky and loose.  
 Rappelling the main face can be done from a few small ceders on top of the cliff, your anchor should be within 10 feet of the top to insure the ends touch, TIE KNOTS a 60M rope just reaches. This is a fantastic and completely hanging rappel after the first 10 feet.
